body:
I _think_ the reason we were glued to the ~1.4~ ish less was that the compiled output had line breaks.  Is there an option for that here? 

Edit: It looks like you can use clean-css http://lesscss.org/#using-less-command-line-usage which allows you to enable line breaks https://github.com/GoalSmashers/clean-css#how-to-use-clean-css-cli .  I can bring it up at the dev meeting today.
Great; thanks.
+1, would also love to have kind of script to generate theme like [that](https://gist.github.com/Carreau/11095832).

@jdfreder we pinned the version because output changed substantially across versions, and we didn't want it to keep changing with users having different less versions. A one-time upgrade makes sense (and pinning to the new version).
According to http://lesscss.org/usage/#command-line-usage-clean-css, clean-css doesn't support sourcemaps yet.  However, they are working on it: https://github.com/GoalSmashers/clean-css/issues/125
From the dev meeting it sounds like we are thumbs up to merge this, but I'll let someone else click the button just in case I'm wrong.
Yes, I wanted to investigate something about comments before hitting the button.
I opened jasongrout/ipython#4 with some comments to separate the style blocks. I don't know how great it is.
BTW, did we decide something between CamelCase and underscore_separated_varaible_name ?
I think we were following our underscore convention.

> I think we were following our underscore convention.

I just remember discussion where we said we should stay close to bootstrap one, and same with css classes using Dashes. Just don't remember the end decision.

I think we should refactor our css in significant ways. Part of that would
be moving to using `-` rather than `_` in the names. In the meantime I am
fine with either.

On Sun, Jul 20, 2014 at 1:17 PM, Matthias Bussonnier <
notifications@github.com> wrote:

> I think we were following our underscore convention.
> 
> I just remember discussion where we said we should stay close to bootstrap
> one, and same with css classes using Dashes. Just don't remember the end
> decision.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/ipython/ipython/pull/6149#issuecomment-49558216.

## 

Brian E. Granger
Cal Poly State University, San Luis Obispo
@ellisonbg on Twitter and GitHub
bgranger@calpoly.edu and ellisonbg@gmail.com
Seem to be hackpad may 15, will relook at the video.
I may have totally forgotten about that. The js/css way is definitely camelCaseVariables and hyphenated-css-classes, if we want to adopt those conventions in our js.

I guess the alternative is to follow PEP 8 everywhere ;-)

But I hadn't planned on changing the JS side of things though.

On Sun, Jul 20, 2014 at 1:24 PM, Min RK notifications@github.com wrote:

> I may have totally forgotten about that. The js/css way is definitely
> camelCaseVariables and hyphenated-css-classes, if we want to adopt those
> conventions in our js.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/ipython/ipython/pull/6149#issuecomment-49558424.

## 

Brian E. Granger
Cal Poly State University, San Luis Obispo
@ellisonbg on Twitter and GitHub
bgranger@calpoly.edu and ellisonbg@gmail.com
Sorry, I was thinking of LESS variables, not js ones.
I rebased this PR and reordered/combined commits (including Min's) so that we only commit the compiled CSS files once.  @minrk, do you want to look at it again?
I think this is good to go. Refactoring naming conventions should be done in a separate PR.
+1, the naming convention is at least uniform inside IPython files.
So is there anything holding back merging this?  Is there a policy about who or when the merge button is pushed?

> So is there anything holding back merging this? Is there a policy about who or when the merge button is pushed?

Nope.

I've just realised that this means that every PR touching CSS will conflict when they're merged, which is going to be a constant annoyance. Min pointed out that it's relatively easy to fix the conflicts, but even so, it's a pain to be rebasing PRs all the time.

My feeling is that this is sufficient reason to revert to a version of less that spreads its output over multiple lines again.
What a pain. Can you remind me if there is a way to run more recent versions of less without going to a single line CSS file?
IIRC there is, but it doesn't work with source maps, which is the reason we were upgrading in the first place.

Ahh crap. The source maps would really, really help in working with CSS. Especially for new developers and designers who are browsing our CSS on the page in the Chrome Dev Tools et at. I am probably +1 on merging this even though the rebase management will be a total pain. Also, I don't want us to get into the habit of using an old version of less in the long run.

Do source maps _require_ (from an implementation perspective) using a single line CSS output? I am wondering if we could submit an issue to less to fix this issue or if it is a fundamental problem induced by using source maps.
I think it was just something that needs doing in less, so we may be able to file an issue.
It's actually CleanCSS that needs the fix (the option to newer versions of less is to tell it to use Clean CSS as the minifier), and there's already an issues for it: GoalSmashers/clean-css#125
And there's a comment there saying that it's the key feature for version 2.3, so fingers crossed.

Maybe more forward with this merge and keep that in mind for the future?

On Wed, Jul 23, 2014 at 12:23 PM, Thomas Kluyver notifications@github.com
wrote:

> And there's a comment there saying that it's the key feature for version
> 2.3, so fingers crossed.
